bunch.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: a group of things that are fastened, held, or growing together
bunch.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: I’ll send her a bunch of flowers.
He had a bunch of keys on his belt.
bunch.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: The ancient Egyptians were a clever bunch.
bunch.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: a large number of people or things, or a large amount of something
bunch.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: There’s a whole bunch of places I want to visit.
bunch.translation[0].note_box[0].section: I picked a bunch of flowers from the garden.
A bunch of keys dangled from his belt.
She served the cheese with a bunch of black grapes.
Bunches of bananas hung in the trees.
You might like to add a bunch of fresh herbs to the stock.
bunch.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to stay close together in a group, or to make people do this
bunch.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: The children bunched together in small groups.
John stopped, forcing the rest of the group to bunch up behind him.
bunch.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to make part of your body tight, or to become tight like this
bunch.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: to pull material together tightly in folds
bunch.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: She bunched the cloth up and threw it away.
bunch.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: to hold or tie things together in a bunch
